---- Journal Entry ----

Markius Albright, after having aided me against Xanthar and his would be assassins, approached me in the Imperial District, claiming to have news of a plot against the lives of both my father and myself.  Markius had heard rumor that Mikel Ravenclaw, a local thug in the Market District, may be the mastermind behind this plan to end my family line.  I found it hard to believe that a cowardly rogue such as Mikel would dare make a move on my father's life, but Markius felt that the truth must be discovered with all haste, as it was rumored that another attack was imminent.  He suggested paying a visit to the Ravenclaw Tavern in the Market District to see what evidence could be uncovered to support these rumors.

---- Journal Entry ----

I convinced Officer Ganolin to send several of his men to Ravenclaw Tavern for assistance in my investigation of Mikel Ravenclaw's guilt.  Ganolin assured me that the men would be awaiting my arrival to the tavern.

---- Journal Entry ----

I found my way into the chamber of Mikel Ravenclaw, seeking to discover whether he was truly behind the attempt on my life by the docks, and hoping to find any clues of further plans to attack my father and me.

Mikel ordered his men to attack me, a bold move for one such as he. It appeared he did indeed have some sort of involvement in the plot against my family, but I still suspected someone else to be the true culprit masterminding this plan. Even if Mikel carried influence in the Market District, he was not so powerful as to assault Imperial interests without some sort of aid...

---- Journal Entry ----

I discovered Chancellor Varhun, my father's aide in city affairs, had prompted Mikel Ravenclaw to set up the failed attempt on my life.  I considered this to be dire news indeed, for Varhun was a high ranking Imperial official, in a position allowing him great freedom to set up another such attack.  From what I had gathered, it seemed Varhun was more interested in seeing my father "removed" from his office of City Magistrate, but felt I should be slain as well to avoid any sort of retribution.

I felt it might be dangerous to immediately approach the Chancellor with this news, for if Varhun wants me dead, I would rather not give him the opportunity to do so in the privacy of his own chambers. It seems wisest to approach Captain Anagril with my suspicions first so that I can enlist his help should things get ugly...

---- Journal Entry ----

I found a letter in Varhun's desk, but it had been burned to ashes. I knew I shouldn't have confronted him with my suspicions prior to speaking to Captain Anagril! Whatever evidence of the Chancellor's guilt the note once held, it's of no use to me now...

Captain Anagril was not able to press any charges against Varhun, for I could recover no evidence capable of proving his guilt.  Varhun, a smug expression upon his face, ordered the two of us out of his chambers, and there was little we could do but comply...

Still, I was sure Varhun had some part in this plot, and I feared my father may already be in grave danger.  It occurred to me that I might should visit my father at our home in the Imperial Estate to warn him of the possibility of attack, even though he had ordered I stay away from the mansion...

---- Journal Entry ----

After being faced with the possibility of arrest and execution, Varhun grew desperate and attacked me in his chambers. I was forced to slay the Chancellor in self-defense, unable to discover what he may have set in store for my father...

The Chancellor's last words kept ringing in my ears: "You will be too late to save your father..."

Even though my father had ordered me to stay away from our home at the Imperial Estate, it seemed wise to go warn him of the possibility of the Chancellor's treachery, before it was too late...

Assassins

---- Journal Entry ----

Instructor Jarvis, my mentor at the Imperial Academy, is presiding over the final ceremony of my graduating class. Janthos, Alia, and I have completed our training and are now to become full citizens of the Sharakhan Empire.

After all my years of training, I feel a twinge of something in me, maybe guilt. I will miss the company of Instructor Jarvis and the friendship of my peers but this day marks the shaping of my own destiny. A destiny that I hope leads me far from my father's city.

---- Journal Entry ----

The Rite of Citizenship at the Academy has three parts. The first part is the Welcoming, where Instructor Jarvis will formally greet us as his students for the last time. Second comes the Judgement where I, as the Magistrate's son, will speak on behalf of my classmates in the judging of a criminal in Emperor Rakha's keeping. The third and final part of the ritual involves the choosing of the Crests of Rakha, which serve as a reward for our service and a token of our new status as full citizens. This is an important day and I wish my father was here to bear witness to it. Alas, he has not yet made an appearance.

---- Journal Entry ----

After all my years of training, I feel a twinge of something in me, maybe guilt. I will miss the company of Instructor Jarvis and the friendship of my peers but this day marks the shaping of my own destiny. A destiny that I hope leads me far from my father's city.

For some reason, my father has not yet arrived. Hopefully he will be here shortly.

---- Journal Entry ----

I have pronounced a Judgement on behalf of my classmates. Instructor Jarvis eyes me calmly, waiting for me to approach him so he can continue with the ceremony. Gilles still has not returned with my father, however, and I am reluctant for this all to be over before he arrives to see my accomplishments.

---- Journal Entry ----

As I lit the remaining brazier, it seemed as though the statue of Rakha nearby came alive, and I could have sworn it was carefully watching my movements...  All that remained of the Ritual of Rakha was to return to Instructor Jarvis, who would walk me through the last portion of the ceremony...

---- Journal Entry ----

The Ritual of Rakha consisted of several components.  The first stage of the ritual involved obtaining the Flames of Faith from the priests in the Imperial Academy, who would test my dedication to Rakha before deeming me fit to pass further along in the ceremony.  With the Flames of Faith, I would be able to light the braziers resting near the statue of Rakha, after which, I was to return to Instructor Jarvis for further instructions on completing the Ritual of Rakha...

---- Journal Entry ----

Instructor Jarvis, my mentor at the Imperial Academy, informed me that to complete my graduation, I must take the Ritual of Rakha, a series of symbolic tests designed to enforce the bond between myself and the Great Savior.  Only then would I be worthy of the honor to depart the Imperial Academy as a graduate of its training.

After all the time I had spent practicing for this moment, a simple ritual seemed of little consequence if it would bring me closer to shaping my own destiny for a change, free of my father's rule...

---- Journal Entry ----

As I approached the statue of Rakha, I found that I could not bring myself to pledge eternal service to the Great Savior.  Perhaps it was only my fear of proclaiming such strong loyalty to any man, but regardless of the reason, I found myself hesitating, even after all the preparation I had made for this day.  Jarvis will likely be quite upset, but I believe I made the choice most fitting to my nature...

---- Journal Entry ----

Upon approaching the statue of Rakha, I knew that I was expected to recite the Oath of Servility to pass the graduation ceremony.  It should have been a simple procedure, but I found myself growing angry at the great lengths of time I was forced to spend in the service of the Great Savior. 

Why should I pledge my eternal service to Rakha?  Why should I not choose my own destiny?  These questions rang loudly in my mind, and I voiced my concerns and anger, refusing to bow before the statue.  

I was uncertain what Instructor Jarvis' reaction would be, but even if it meant passing up all that I had trained for, I could not bring myself to complete the Ritual of Rakha...

All that remained was to speak with Jarvis, and determine what fate would befall me for my failure...

Citizen of the Empire

---- Journal Entry ----

The Crimson Prophet, leader of the rebellion against the Sharakhan Empire, spoke to his followers outside the wreckage of my home. From what I could gather of their discussion, it seemed the Crimson Prophet had tricked my father into meeting with him. It was all a trap, however, and my father was brutally murdered at the Prophet's hands.

The Crimson Prophet mentioned that he had other business to attend to in the city, something regarding the recovery of an item stolen from him. I was to be executed as a warning to the other Imperials. My days would have ended there, if not for a timely rescue...

Once again, Markius Albright came to my aid, fighting off the Crimson Prophet's fanatical followers...

---- Journal Entry ----

I spoke with Markius Albright after he rescued me from certain death at the hands of the Crimson Prophet.  He informed me that the Prophet's followers had launched an assault on Ghaarak, and that the city would likely fall under their might.  Markius worried for my safety, and asked that I accept an offer from him to take me to safety.

He wished for me to accompany him to the city Docks, where a ship of his, the Voyager, lay in wait.  There, Markius claimed he could keep me safe from the Crimson Prophet's machinations.

I was unsure what to make of these new events, but even in the seclusion of the Imperial Estate grounds, I could hear battle raging within the city districts.  I thought perhaps Markius had a valid point, and that escape from this city under seige might not be such a bad idea...

I came upon Captain Anagril in the Imperial District of Ghaarak, where signs of a massive battle could be seen everywhere.  The Captain informed me of the plight the city had fallen under, a tale which brought a chill to my bones...

Apparently, the city's attackers had staged a clever assault on Ghaarak.  A group of sorcerers, posing as Rakha's own elite High Sorcerers, had come to the Imperial Grand Hall.  Anagril claimed to have been a bit suspicious, but gave it little heed, as he did not understand the ways of the arcane.  When the opportunity presented itself, these treacherous sorcerers revealed their true nature, and murdered High Sorcerer Zhiram in the Grand Hall grounds. 

Taking possession of the Control Stone, the traitors turned the Imperial District's defenses against the citizens.  The gate to the Market District was sealed by the sorceries of the Control Stone, trapping the Imperial citizens within the district.  Unleashing the followers of the Crimson Prophet upon the Imperial District to slaughter any who stood in their way, it was only a matter of time before the Crimson Followers stood poised to conquer the Imperials.

Anagril and those who still had strength to fight had been resisting the attackers, but he feared they cannot hold out for long...

---- Journal Entry ----

After rescuing me from certain death at the hands of the Crimson Prophet, I spoke with Markius Albright.  He informed me that the Prophet's followers had launched an assault on Ghaarak, and that the city would likely fall under their might.  Markius worried for my safety, and asked that I accept an offer from him to take me to safety.

He wished for me to accompany him to the city Docks, where a ship of his, the Voyager, lay in wait.  There, Markius claimed he could keep me safe from the Crimson Prophet's machinations.

I was unsure what to make of these new events, but even in the seclusion of the Imperial Estate grounds, I could hear battle raging within the city districts.  I thought perhaps Markius had a valid point, and that escape from this city under seige might not be such a bad idea...

---- Journal Entry ----

The Crimson Prophet, leader of the rebellion against the Sharakhan Empire, spoke to his followers outside the wreckage of my home. From what I could gather of their discussion, it seemed the Crimson Prophet had tricked my father into meeting with him. It was all a trap, however, and my father was brutally murdered at the Prophet's hands.

The Crimson Prophet mentioned that he had other business to attend to in the city, something regarding the recovery of an item stolen from him. I was to be executed as a warning to the other Imperials. My days would have ended there, if not for a timely rescue...

Once again, Markius Albright came to my aid, fighting off the Crimson Prophet's fanatical followers...

---- Journal Entry ----

Imperial Captain Anagril claimed the only way to save the Imperial District was to retake the Control Stone at the Imperial Grand Hall.  Doing so would allow the seal around the Market Gates to be lifted, and grant the Imperial citizens an escape route from the doomed district.  

Anagril saw two options available: a direct assault upon the Grand Hall, or discovering a rumored secret passage into the building.  The Captain did not know much of the secret passage other than various whisperings he had heard, but he did offer to lead his remaining men in an assault on the Grand Hall if I thought it would help.

In the wake of my father's death, it was left to me to make this decision.  I could only hope to make the right one...

---- Journal Entry ----

Upon entering the harbor at the Docks, I came upon Markius Albright and his companions, standing bravely in defiance of the Crimson Prophet.  The Crimson Prophet's might must be great indeed, for he easily withstood their assault, flinging Markius and his companions back as a person would annoying flies.

Markius and his companions were unable to stop the Crimson Prophet's plans, and he escaped from the Docks upon one of his ships... but not before conjuring a set of demons to keep his assailers at bay.

We found ourselves faced with a pack of howling, horrible demons... ones who seemed bent on shortly ending our lives...

As I prepared to enter Markius' ship, the Voyager, I turned to look upon my home city of Ghaarak one last time... and saw only the bright lights of the fires burning in the distance.  Ghaarak had fallen, and there was little more I could do... save go with Markius and his companions.  Perhaps a time would come when I would find vengeance for what occurred in Ghaarak, but it was not to be that day.  That day, only survival mattered, and I slowly descended into the ship's hold, unknowingly embarking upon my destiny as one of the Shadowguard...

Escape from Ghaarak

---- Journal Entry ----

Many times I wondered why my father, the "legendary" hero Okaris, insisted that I come to live with him in the city of Ghaarak, among the wild, untamed lands of the Northern Reaches.  I suppose he felt that I should be with him after my mother perished to the Red Plague several years ago.  Father's duties as the Magistrate of Ghaarak kept him busy, however, and I could not help but feel that he considered my presence to be more a nuisance than anything else.  Though we lived under the same roof, we rarely spoke to one another, and the rift between us had grown quite large...

I had been enrolled in the Imperial Academy of Ghaarak, its small stature a clear indicator that the Empire holds a far weaker sway so far along its frontier than in the heartlands of the south.  I had completed the basic training offered by the Imperial Academy, a prestigious achievement even if most of my learning occurred long before we arrived in these desolate northern lands.  Father had made quite a fuss over my graduation from the Academy, actually deeming this subject to be worthy of his time, though I believe he merely wished for me to follow in his footsteps, continuing his mission to unite all the lands of the Northern Reaches under the Empire's banners.  Still, it was nice to know he at least had acknowledged my presence for a change...

---- Journal Entry ----

As usual, my father was not around when a matter of importance arose in my life, and he had failed to arrive at the time of my graduation ceremony.  The servant of our house, Gilles, went to see what is keeping my father, while suggesting I speak with Imperial Instructor Jarvis to begin the ceremony.  Gilles seemed to believe my father would hurry to the Academy once he realized he was late, but I had my doubts...  After all, it seemed my father was entirely too busy at being Magistrate to pay any heed of his only child's accomplishments...

With little hope that my father would actually change his ways, I took Gilles advice, and began the graduation ceremony while waiting for my father to arrive...

---- Journal Entry ----

The rift growing between my father and me had never been felt as greatly as it did on the day of my graduation, for it seemed even such a prestigious ceremony was not of enough importance to interrupt his affairs.  I knew father would make all manner of excuses for his absence, just as he always did after missing an affair of importance to me.  

My instructor at the Imperial Academy informed me that my talents, coupled with my position as child of Magistrate Okaris, had drawn the attention of the ShadowGuard, one of the Sharakhan Empire's elite organizations. I was told that I should try to maintain a state of impressive behavior, as these recruiters would likely be keeping an eye on me from a distance to judge my possible worth.

---- Journal Entry ----

Our house servant, Gilles, brought me a message from my father, claiming he was terribly sorry for having missed the graduation ceremony, but hoped to make it up to me later in the day.  This time it was an emergency council meeting with foreign visitors.  To be honest, the reasons had grown unimportant to me, for I had come to anticipate such news from my father...

Gilles suggested that I take some time to visit the Market District until my father sent for me.  I supposed there wasn't much else to do in the city,  and decided to take his advice to heart.

Father's duties as the Magistrate of Ghaarak kept him busy, however, and I could not help but feel that he considered my presence to be more a nuisance than anything else.  Though we lived under the same roof, we rarely spoke to one another, and the rift between us had grown quite large...

I had been enrolled in the Imperial Academy of Ghaarak, its small stature a clear indicator that the Empire holds a far weaker sway so far along its frontier than in the heartlands of the south.  I had completed the basic training offered by the Imperial Academy, a prestigious achievement even if most of my learning occurred long before we arrived in these desolate northern lands.  Father had made quite a fuss over my graduation from the Academy, actually deeming this subject to be worthy of his time, though I believe he merely wished for me to follow in his footsteps, continuing his mission to unite all the lands of the Northern Reaches under the Empire's banners.  Still, it was nice to know he at least had acknowledged my presence for a change...

---- Journal Entry ----

While in the Market District, I witnessed a most unusual event.  Right in the center of the main plaza, a mysterious red robed figure appeared from thin air, speaking words of impending doom for the people of Ghaarak, unless they turned their backs on the Sharakhan Empire.  

I wasn't sure what portent this event held, but a man at the plaza seemed quite distraught over the prophet's appearance, and quickly went in pursuit.  I wondered if my father had yet heard news of this event, for I was sure it would be of great interest to him to know of this occurrence.

---- Journal Entry ----

The rift growing between my father and me had never been felt as greatly as it did on the day of my graduation, for it seemed even such a prestigious ceremony was not of enough importance to interrupt his affairs.  I knew father would make all manner of excuses for his absence, just as he always did after missing an affair of importance to me.  

My instructor at the Imperial Academy informed me that my talents, coupled with my position as child of Magistrate Okaris, had drawn the attention of the ShadowGuard, one of the Sharakhan Empire's elite organizations. I was told that I should try to maintain a state of impressive behavior, as these recruiters would likely be keeping an eye on me from a distance to judge my possible worth.

Gilles came to me upon my arrival in the Imperial District, and brought word that my father had heard of the assassination attempt on my life in the Market District, and wished to speak with me at once regarding my safety.  I supposed that I should go speak with him at his Council Chambers in the Imperial Grand Hall, for matters seemed to have grown grave in Ghaarak, and both of our lives appeared to be at stake...

---- Journal Entry ----

---- Journal Entry ----

Upon arriving at my father's council chamber, I witnessed the end of his meeting with two other men, one named Vhorkas, an aged man who seemed well accustomed to battle, and a sorcerer named Harkon, whom I recognized from the incident in the Market District with that strange prophet.  

The three of them spoke for quite some time regarding issues I do not even claim to understand fully.  It seemed my father had placed some sort of gem, found at a strange excavation site in the Northern Reaches, under lock and key in the Imperial Treasury.  He seemed quite worried that this gem was having some sort of unusual effect upon all who came into contact with it.  The sorcerer, Harkon, pleaded with my father to allow him to take it back to a place called Zhantara, but my father refused his request.  In anger, Harkon left the chamber...

After the sorcerer's departure, I overheard my father and the man named Vhorkas speak in length.  It appeared that they were old friends, and knew each other quite well.  My father spoke a bit about me, saying he was concerned over my safety.  This Vhorkas made a vague mention of me joining some "order" of his, but the conversation was cut short when my father finally spotted me and called for me to come speak with him...

---- Journal Entry ----

The messenger claimed I should speak to Xanthar to learn more, and quickly departed before I could ask any further questions...

---- Journal Entry ----

I spoke with my father in his Council Chambers, and he seemed quite concerned over my safety after the assassination attempt on my life.  He did not seem himself, making many vague mentionings of Ghaarak being in danger, while eluding any details as to what they may be.  I had never seen my father act in such a fashion, for he was usually quite direct in his dealings with others, including me.  

As the conversation came to an end, my father told me how much he cared for me, and seemed to be resigning himself to some sort of decision.  He said he was going to return to the Imperial Estate which we called home, and make a deal which would ensure my safety, and hopefully that of Ghaarak as well...  

My father told me he would prefer that I avoid our home for a short while, at least until he could conclude his meeting and send for me.  

I was unsure of what to make of all this, and left with many questions unanswered, as well as feeling of unease...

Upon arriving at the Imperial Estate that has been home to my father and I since our arrival in Ghaarak, disaster befell us.  A great blast shook through our home just as I approached its doors, assuredly killing all inside, including my father, in the raging inferno.

I was only narrowly saved when a gleaming medallion lying upon the doorstep caught my interest.  Stooping to pick it up, I was not in harm's reach when the blast destroyed my home and killed my father...

Father

---- Journal Entry ----

After joining Tarin Lightfingers at a card table in the Market District, one of his fellow card players, a Minotaur named Ghan, grew very upset after losing his gold to the Halfling, and demolished the table where they were playing.  I remember wondering what terrible circumstances could possibly lead the Minotaur to erupt into such a rage...

---- Journal Entry ----

After joining Tarin Lightfingers at a card table in the Market District, one of his fellow card players, a Minotaur named Ghan, grew very upset after losing his gold to the Halfling, and demolished the table where they were playing.  

We listened as Ghan told the story of how he had lost his "soul brooch", an item exchanged between Minotaur lovers to seal their life bond, while playing cards with a fellow named Mylok in the Market District.  Ghan was quite upset over the whole ordeal, and felt that he has brought shame and dishonor to his name, as well as that of his love, Vhaarah.

---- Journal Entry ----

Tarin Lightfingers asked that I aid him in recovering the  Soul Brooch for his Minotaur friend, Ghan.  The Soul Brooch was in the custody of Mylok, a crooked gambler in the Market District who swindled the brooch from Ghan.  Tarin promised me a reward if I would bring the Soul Brooch back into his possession, at which time he would try and find a way to return the brooch to the Minotaur without risking shame to Ghan's name.

---- Journal Entry ----

After joining Tarin Lightfingers at a card table in the Market District, one of his fellow card players, a Minotaur named Ghan, grew very upset after losing his gold to the Halfling, and demolished the table where they were playing.  

We listened as Ghan told the story of how he had lost his "soul brooch", an item exchanged between Minotaur lovers to seal their life bond, while playing cards with a fellow named Mylok in the Market District.  Ghan was quite upset over the whole ordeal, and felt that he has brought shame and dishonor to his name, as well as that of his love, Vhaarah.

---- Journal Entry ----

I recovered Ghan's Soul Brooch from Mylok, and I must confess I was amazed at its exquisite craftsmanship.  I knew such a jewel would surely fetch a great price in the Market District, but doing so would require breaking my promise to Tarin, and robbing Ghan of any chance to recover his honor...

---- Journal Entry ----

---- Journal Entry ----

Deciding to revoke my promise to Tarin Lightfingers, I opted to keep the Soul Brooch for myself, perhaps to sell it for a hefty sum at one of the Market shops.  Tarin was ill pleased at my decision, but there truly was little he could do about it...

---- Journal Entry ----

I foolishly spoke with Ghan regarding his Soul Brooch, and he grew angry at the mention that I might aid him in recovering it, saying such an act would only shame his honor further.  Even if I were to have recovered the brooch, Ghan would have refused to take it from me...

---- Journal Entry ----

As I had promised Tarin, I returned the Soul Brooch into Ghan the Minotaur's possession.  The Minotaur was most pleased to have his beloved jewel returned to him, and seemed quite grateful of our aid...

---- Journal Entry ----

After the ordeal of the Minotaur's brooch, I spoke once more with Tarin, but our conversation was interrupted by a strange man...

---- Journal Entry ----

After the ordeal of the Minotaur's brooch, I spoke once more with Tarin, but our conversation was interrupted by a strange man calling himself Malthar.  This Malthar invited Tarin, along with Lyen, a ranger with a cold disposition who considers Tarin a close friend, to a friendly game of cards at his table, an offer I now know the Halfling rarely, if ever, refuses.  The invitation was extended to me, as well, and it seemed harmless enough to enjoy a few drinks and a bit of fun among the patrons at the Ravenclaw Tavern...

---- Journal Entry ----

After the ordeal of the Minotaur's brooch, I spoke once more with Tarin, but our conversation was interrupted by a strange man calling himself Malthar.  This Malthar invited Tarin, along with his companion, Lyen Silverblade, to a friendly game of cards at his table, an offer I now know the Halfling rarely, if ever, refuses.  The invitation was extended to me, as well, and it seemed harmless enough to enjoy a few drinks and a bit of fun among the patrons at the Ravenclaw Tavern...

I was soon to find that I was wrong in my assumption.  After joining the group at their table, Malthar began questioning Tarin on some sort of past scandal in the city of Laceri.  Evidently, Tarin owed quite a debt to a local crime lord of Laceri, a fellow by the name of Pharos Nightcrawler, and a sizeable bounty had been placed on Tarin's head.  Malthar and his men were agents of Pharos Nightcrawler, and intended to collect the price on the Halfling's head.  Poisoning the drinks at the table, Malthar and his men hurried away with the prone body of Tarin in tow...

---- Journal Entry ----

I discovered that Malthar and his men were likely in hiding near the boathouse of the Market District, where they had often been seen moving about.  It seemed as good a place as any to begin the search for Tarin...

---- Journal Entry ----

I spied Malthar entering an old trapdoor below the boathouse in the Market District, muttering something about awaiting a man named "Halgok".  Judging by his worried tone, I imagined it was safe to assume he had Tarin located somewhere near the boathouse...

An idea came to my mind in Malthar's underground lair, one that might allow me to infiltrate the Nightcrawler abode with stealth.  Since Malthar seemed to be awaiting another of his cronies to arrive by ship, if I were to don one of the Nightcrawler outfits, I felt I might be able to pose as a representative of this Halgok, and convince the doorman to let me gain entry without combat.  It seemed a desperate ploy, but one which just might work...

Evidently, Tarin owed quite a debt to a local crime lord of Laceri, a fellow by the name of Pharos Nightcrawler, and a sizeable bounty had been placed on Tarin's head.  Malthar and his men were agents of Pharos Nightcrawler, and intended to collect the price on the Halfling's head.  Poisoning the drinks at the table, Malthar and his men hurried away with the prone body of Tarin in tow...

---- Journal Entry ----

Upon hearing Overlord Vhorkas mention my father, I could not help but think back on that day, six months ago, when all of this started:  my acceptance into the Shadowguard order, my coming to this secret isle... leaving my home behind forever...

These thoughts inevitably lead to my father, and as the memories come rushing back to me, I cannot help but succumb to them...

---- Journal Entry ----

Overlord Vhorkas came to me in the Shadowguard barracks as I wrote in my journal, recalling the events leading to my father's demise.  He spoke to me briefly of the Final Initiation I am to take on the morrow, congratulating me for earning Emperor Rakha's trust after such a short time among their ranks.

The Overlord suggested I take some rest, to keep up my strength for the Final Initiation in the morning.  He did say I could speak with the other Shadowguard members in their quarters if I were concerned as to what the Final Initiation may entail.  

The exhaustion brought from my memories of the past has begun to catch up with me, and I believe the Overlord is correct... I could use some rest if tomorrow is to be a strenuous day...

---- Journal Entry ----

And so the tale is told...  I had not thought back on those times leading to my coming to the Shadowguard in quite a few months, and I must say it is a relief to have finally written it all down on the page.  To forget one's past is to forget that which makes us whole... so the Almighty Rakha teaches.  Perhaps he is correct in this matter, for I do feel as though a heavy burden has been lifted from me.

But now is the time to look to the future.  Who knows what it may hold in store?  What wonders may be on the horizon? 

All I know is that being amongst the ranks of the Shadowguard shall almost certainly provide quite a bit of excitement in the years to come...
Memories of the Past...

---- Journal Entry ----

I first met Markius Albright upon the streets of the Market District in Ghaarak, when he asked if I would listen to a proposal of his.  At the time, I did not trust the look of him, and I refused his request.

Markius , being the man of few words that he is, respectfully accepted my refusal, but he did say I could return to speak with him at a later time if I so desired.

---- Journal Entry ----

I first met Markius Albright on the streets of the Market District in Ghaarak, where he asked that I aid him in bringing an end to a slave trade within the city, led by a group of slavers known as the Bloodhawks.  Markius suggested I approach Shrak, a merchant operating in the Market District, as it was rumored he had connections with the Bloodhawks, and might know of their base's whereabouts.  Markius offered me a reward for bringing him the location of the Bloodhawks' slave pen.

---- Journal Entry ----

Though I was unable to discover the exact location of the Bloodhawk base in the city, I did learn that two of the slaver group's members were staying at the Ravenclaw Tavern here in the Market District, serving as Shrak's contacts within the organization.  I learned that entry to these slavers' room could be gained by knocking three times upon their room door, and speaking the phrase: "The hawk's blood flows freely..."

I believed Markius Albright would find this information most useful, and planned to return to him with the information...

Shrak told me that he would arrange for these Bloodhawks to ambush Markius if I could bring him to their chamber, and that they would see Lyen no longer interfered with the slaver operations in the city... 

Shrak offered me a reward of 300 gold pieces for this aid, which I could collect once the deed was done.

---- Journal Entry ----

After aiding Markius in defeating the Bloodhawks of Ghaarak, led by Jhordak the slaver, he gave me thanks for my assistance. Markius mentioned that we may yet cross paths, and bid me farewell for the time being. Even then, I felt a strong premonition that his words were true, and I had not seen the last of Markius Albright...
Slavers in Ghaarak

---- Journal Entry ----

After the incident with Nelgir the merchant and the restless spirit of his father, I found myself approached by several men of frightening appearance.  They had heard of the strange spirit's summoning, and wished to know where they might find the woman responsible for it.  The men offered me a reward of 500 gold pieces if I told them where Kara was, but I hesitated to tell them, for I could sense that their purpose could only be evil, and had a hunch that if they were to get their hands on Kara, she would suffer for it...

On first meeting these men, I refused to have anything to do with them.  Their leader, a fearful fellow named Ghasaran, told me to return to him if I decided I would indeed enjoy the reward he promised...

---- Journal Entry ----

After the incident with Nelgir the merchant and the restless spirit of his father, I found myself approached by several men of frightening appearance.  They had heard of the strange spirit's summoning, and wished to know where they might find the woman responsible for it.  The men offered me a reward of 500 gold pieces if I told them where Kara was, but I hesitated to tell them, for I could sense that their purpose could only be evil, and had a hunch that if they were to get their hands on Kara, she would suffer for it...

Going on my gut instinct, I mislead these strange men, telling them Kara had gone to the docks.  They paid me half of my payment up front, and promised the other half if I were to come ensure they captured her with no trouble.  Of course I had no intention of meeting these men again...

Knowing that my ruse would likely only buy Kara a brief period of time, I thought it might be best to warn her of her stalkers...

---- Journal Entry ----

After the incident with Nelgir the merchant and the restless spirit of his father, I found myself approached by several men of frightening appearance.  They had heard of the strange spirit's summoning, and wished to know where they might find the woman responsible for it.  The men offered me a reward of 500 gold pieces if I told them where Kara was, but I hesitated to tell them, for I could sense that their purpose could only be evil, and had a hunch that if they were to get their hands on Kara, she would suffer for it...

I refused to tell the men anything of Kara's whereabouts, for I could not bring myself to mislead them untruthfully, and would have felt wrong taking their gold, no matter what my personal feelings as their nature may have been.  The men were angry, claiming they would find Kara one way or another, and stormed off.

I felt that Kara would likely be interested in knowing of these stalkers, perhaps giving her time to escape in case they meant her any harm...

---- Journal Entry ----

Janthos the Inventor, a Gnomish wizard with whom I often trained at the Academy, had been hard at work trying to establish a power source for the constructs in the Imperial District which would grant them greater freedom from the power of the Control Stone, enhancing their usefulness to the Imperial settlers here in Ghaarak.  However, he had not yet found a power source suitable to do so.  If I could find such a power source for Janthos, I was sure he would be quite appreciative of my aid.

---- Journal Entry ----

Janthos the Inventor, a Gnomish wizard with whom I often trained at the Academy, had been hard at work trying to establish a power source for the constructs in the Imperial District which would grant them greater freedom from the power of the Control Stone, enhancing their usefulness to the Imperial settlers here in Ghaarak.  However, he had not yet found a power source suitable to do so.  

I knew Irilium Crystals were often used for just such purposes as Janthos had in mind, but they were in rare supply in the northern lands of the frontier.  I decided that it might be wise to keep an eye out for any Irilium Crystals around the city of Ghaarak.

---- Journal Entry ----

Janthos the Inventor, a Gnomish wizard with whom I often trained at the Academy, had been hard at work trying to establish a power source for the constructs in the Imperial District which would grant them greater freedom from the power of the Control Stone, enhancing their usefulness to the Imperial settlers here in Ghaarak.  

I knew Irilium Crystals were often used for just such purposes as Janthos had in mind, but they were in rare supply in the northern lands of the frontier.  Janthos asked that I procure several Irilium Crystals for his experiment, and suggested I start my search in the Market District.

---- Journal Entry ----

Janthos the Inventor was quite pleased when I brought him the Irilium Crystals for his constructs.  He planned to begin work on the ritual to infuse the constructs with the Irilium Crystals' power, and hoped that he may achieve his goal by the end of the day.

---- Journal Entry ----

I gave Janthos the Inventor the Irilium Crystals he sought, but I had them enchanted by Alia, a druidess concerned over Janthos' tampering with the magic of the constructs.  The druidess' enchantment was designed to cause the crystals to dissolve soon after placement into the constructs, causing a massive meltdown of the constructs' systems.  Alia believed that such an act would bring an end to Janthos' unnatural experiments.
The Gnome's Experiment

---- Journal Entry ----

I saw a mysterious Elven woman at the merchant stand of Nelgir, a gem trader of Ghaarak.  While using her charms in an attempt to distract the merchant, the woman made a move to swipe a rather inexpensive looking gem from Nelgir's possession...  Her ruse did not work, and the crafty trader caught her in the act.  He grabbed her hand and sought to recover the gem from her possession...

In her defense, the woman uttered a dark prayer to Akhana, the Goddess of Death, pleading for aid, and at her call, a spirit of the Underworld emerged...

---- Journal Entry ----

Growing concerned over Nelgir's threats to summon the guards to arrest her on charges of theft, the woman called forth for aid from Akhana, the Goddess of Death.  Her spell went awry, however, and the gem she sought to steal began emitting a strange light.

Suddenly, a spirit from the Underworld emerged nearby, that of an elderly Elven man.  At the sight of this spirit, Nelgir grew very afraid, giving the woamn the chance to swipe her prize and make a hasty escape...

---- Journal Entry ----

Her ruse did not work, and the crafty trader caught her in the act.  He grabbed her hand and sought to recover the gem from her possession...

---- Journal Entry ----

Nelgir, concerned over the effect this summoned spirit would have on his business, asked that I track down the gem thief and discover a way to rid him of the spirit.  He offered me a reward if I could find a way to return the undead being to its rest...

Nelgir suggested I check at the tavern in the Market District, as he believed the Elven woman to be a stranger to Ghaarak, and thought that to be the best place to begin the search.

The spirit said it would not rest unless banished witht he Bloodstong or until Nelgir brought to justice for his father's murder.

The spirit was unsure as to where it had died, but it remembered the place it fell to be a dark, stench filled hole...

---- Journal Entry ----

Upon confronting Kara regarding the issue of the gem theft, I learned that she was in need of her stolen prize, an unremarkable Bloodstone, for a ritual of great importance to her.  She apologized for any trouble she may have caused, but claimed she could not return the Bloodstone to Nelgir.  She did, however, offer to enter a trance and allow the spirit to speak with her, possibly giving insight on a way to disperse its presence.

---- Journal Entry ----

Nelgir, concerned over the effect this summoned spirit would have on his business, asked that I track down the gem thief and discover a way to rid him of the spirit.  He offered me a reward if I could find a way to return the undead being to its rest...

Nelgir suggested I check at the tavern in the Market District, as he believed the Elven woman to be a stranger to Ghaarak, and thought that to be the best place to begin the search.

---- Journal Entry ----

Kara, growing concerned over Nelgir's threats to summon the guards to arrest her on charges of theft, called forth for aid from Akhana, the Goddess of Death.  Her spell went awry, however, and the gem she sought to steal began emitting a strange light.

Suddenly, a spirit from the Underworld emerged nearby, that of an elderly Elven man.  At the sight of this spirit, Nelgir grew very afraid, giving Kara the chance to swipe her prize and make a hasty escape...

---- Journal Entry ----

I first met Kara Dy'nesh at the merchant stand of Nelgir, a gem trader of Ghaarak.  While using her charms in an attempt to distract the merchant, Kara made a move to swipe a rather inexpensive looking gem from Nelgir's possession...  Her ruse did not work, and the crafty trader caught her in the act.  He grabbed her hand and sought to recover the gem from her possession...

---- Journal Entry ----

I used the Bloodstone, which Kara had stolen, to banish the Spirit of Malgor back to the spirit plane. Though Kara is quite upset with my betrayl, the ghost is now gone and I may collect my reward from Nelgir.

---- Journal Entry ----

Deep within the depths of the chamber known only as the Sepulcher, my companions among the Shadowguard order and I have come in search of a jewel called the Heart of Rakha.  Our task is to infiltrate the Sepulcher, and reclaim the Heart of Rakha, locked away somewhere within.  Markius Albright, fearless leader of the Shadowguard, has told us that we must first find a way to pass the Gates of Rakha if we are to have any hope of reclaiming the jewel.

Markius has sent Lyen Silverblade and Kara Dy'nesh, fellow members of the Shadowguard, into the halls of the Sepulcher in search of any clues which might lead to unlocking the Gates of Rakha.  I, being the newest addition to the group, have been given the task of aiding Lyen and Kara in whatever fashion I may.

---- Journal Entry ----

Instructor Jarvis has informed me that my studies have drawn the attention of the ShadowGuard, an elite order in Emperor Rakha's service. To become a ShadowGuard initiate would be quite an honor, both for myself and for the Academy from which I have so recently graduated. A recruiter by the name of Markius Albright apparently awaits me in the Market District.

---- Journal Entry ----

I have met with Markius in the Market District and, though he has not mentioned the ShadowGuard by name, he has requested my assistance in dealing with some sort of trouble in Ghaarak. I can only assume it must be some sort of test.

Markius says that both have rooms at the Ravenclaw Tavern.

---- Journal Entry ----

While looking for Markius in the Market District, I witnessed a most unusual event. Right in the center of the main plaza, a mysterious red robed figure appeared from thin air, speaking words of impending doom for the people of Ghaarak, unless they turned their backs on the Sharakhan Empire.  

I had best put my thoughts of the ShadowGuard aside for now, it appears more serious things are afoot in the city. I'm not sure what portent this event holds, but a man at the plaza seemed quite distraught over the prophet's appearance and quickly went in pursuit. I wonder if my father has yet heard news of this event, for I am sure it would be of great interest to him to know of this occurrence.
